transcript.content: This is Audible.
Podcast jingle
Hello and welcome to the all-new 'Ricky Gervais show' with me, Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant, -
Hello.
- And Karl Pilkington.
Alright?
You say uh, "all-new", Rick..
Yeah.
What - In what way is this all-new? I mean, it seems very similar. It's me, you and Karl. I suspect we're going to be talking bollocks(!)
Ahh..! I'll tell you what's new about it... This time you have to pay for it.
Ha-ha ha! Well, that is a nice new development.
Yeah.
But what about within the content of the show, any of the classic features, Monkey News?
Well, I think Karl retired Monkey News. I don't know why-
It's been axed!
It's just that we'd - we'd sort of done it all.. D'you know what I mean, the-
But will it be coming back in the future?
Uhh.. We might do something with it. Yeah.
Good. I think there'll be a campaign, you know. If I know our listeners - and I DON'T WANT TO,-
Steve chuckles
- then they'll be doin' an Internet campaign now to bring back Monkey News.
I just want a quick q-question because it's - I'm a bit confused. Is this show 13 (cos' we've just done 12); or is this show one of the all-new Ricky Gervais show? I didn't know where we are.
Show one of the all-new Ricky Gervais Show.
Right.
Is it though?
What d'you mean?
Well, that - that's like.. that question that I put to you, about.. Say - say if like, we - I don't know, we - we do something wrong to this world..
Yeah..
Erm.. Runs out of whatever we need. I don't know how it works. Erm..
Hm. You put yourself down. I think you do. No, I think you probably-
No, just - just - whatever -
Go on.
Whatever the reason is, if it [struggling to articulate]-
Air? Run out of air?
You are talking yourself out of a job with NASA, putting yourself down like that. I think you know exactly how the world works...
No-no no, but you know, just like erm...
Say, if we had to go to another world..
Hm.
Right.
What year would it be?
Yeah..

I - I explained, I - told you, it depends.. Because, it doesn't matter where you start, right? It depends what a year is. A 'year' is a year because that's how long it takes our planet to go round our sun. A day is a day because that's how long it takes the world to r-revolve once -
I know, but you can't - you can't go to another world, and then start.. changing everything, cos' people are going to be a bit 'unnervy' about being on different soil.
(brief pause) So its-
But it's not their choice! You can't go to a planet and go, "Hm, we've got to speed this planet up. It's not all going through space quickly enough."
Yeah, but everybody's -- you know, like - especially older people, are set in their ways. Right?
I don't think older people, set in their ways, are gonna pack their bags and go to Mars.
No, but if they have to. (brief pause) Anyway, that - that isn't the point. All - all I'm sayin'-
What? They're going to be moaning about, "Days are shorter here", or "Days are longer, aren't they?"
Well yeah. You know what they like. Change-
But old people don't care. They like short days. They don't get out of bed, do they, until late. They've got nothing to get up for, and they go to bed early.
Yeah, but it's not just that, is it?
What if it's a longer day, Steve..?
Oh, nightmare.
(to Karl) That's your point innit'?
But I'm talking about.. stationery, diaries.. Everything's gonna be a mess.
Right..
So what do you do? If I was in charge..
Go on.
I'd - I'd just say, "Yeah, carry on. It's uh, 2007, it's September, it's a Thursday. Get on with it."
Steve chuckles lightly
Brilliant.
I - I think, because people-
26 Hours later. Uh, with a new day...
And uh, 480 days later, "Oh, it's another year, 2008."
I was trying to explain to him yesterday, uh, in a cafe about telescopes that can see back to the Big Bang, and-
Why.. did you do that..?
Well, I was trying to explain what a light-year was. Then, I was explaining to him that - you know.. You sit down, you - you put your telescope on, you're looking at a star, the star explodes.

That star exploded a million years ago and he couldn't have it. I was going, "you're literally seeing it explode a million years ago because that's how long the light, going-". And I started telling that, you know uh.. Someone on another planet far, far away could be watching the 1980 World Cup Final - if they had a strong enough telescope, because it -
Yeah, yeah.
- that's how long it took to get. Look at him. Look at his face. I - I can see his head bleeding.
I just don't- So are you saying...
Why did you start doing this in a cafe, Rick? Was it a 24 hour cafe? What were you thinking?
Ricky laughs
But are you saying then there could be an alien fella?

No! I'm not saying that at all. I'm saying that just like we can see things happening in other planets, other solar systems that happened millions of years ago, there could be a little alien fella with a telescope watching the Battle of Hastings if he was far enough away.
Do you understand the concept of what Karl's saying? That light is travelling at a certain speed, which means it hasn't necessarily arrived here, yet.
So we could all relive history, though, is what I mean?
No, we couldn't.
Because but it's backwards.
Well, no... One: you'd have to travel faster than the speed of light.
Yeah, I know, but say if we can do all that.
Well, that's the big thing, you can't.
No, I know, but you know, it's only a matter of time, isn't it?
Why haven't we? Hmmmm...
No, but we're not in a rush to do it because we can just go back in time.
Well, but if time travel is possible, right, eventually, then it's already happened and they've come back.
Yeah, I know, but what I mean is it's one of those inventions that we're not in a rush to do, because-
No, what I'm saying is: if it's possible, then it will happen. And if it will happen, it has, it in the future.
Yeah, but we don't know about that yet, do we?
No, but you see my point?
Not really.
Okay.
Yeah, but it's not that great. Just because you're seeing that far, because there's nothing in the way, you're looking at nothing. Space is nothing. What are you looking at?
They say. What do they say? I don't know.
Ricky and Steve laugh
If only you had a saying there! At your fingertips.
What I mean is the universe, they say it's non stop. There's no science to it.
No, don't say that. Scientists have never said that.(laughs)
Heaven forbid.

Now, Karl, I know you're fascinated by the concept of the doppelganger, of seeing someone who looks exactly like you. Jake has emailed in. He says: Karl, if you could spend a day with an exact replica of you, okay, so somehow they've cloned you, Karl, and you've got him for one day, what would you do with this? What would you make him do? What conversation would you have with him? What would you do? Is there anything you could, you know, how would you utilize him for one day?
Well, they'd both say, I'm not bothered, and that'd be the end of conversation.
Yeah
What would do me head in is- does it, Does he think the same way? Look the same way?
Exactly the same.
How would I know which one I was?
Steve laughs
Because you'd be you.
That's amazing!
How would I know which one I was?

Incredible. That is the most stupid thing ever said by a human being! Can we get the Guinness Book Records on this? I mean, out there. Listen, people, have you heard anything more stupid than how would I know which one I was? It's the most stupid thing any human being has ever said. By definition.

But think about it. This Other person's going, alright, thanks for meeting up and that. And I go, hang on a minute. No, you. You came to me and then Suzanne would come home and she wouldn't know the difference. And then suddenly you start doubting yourself and you go, should I be leaving? Or. So how do I know if I am that real one? If he knows what I know?
But you know who you are because you're experiencing.
But he'd be saying that. Because he'd say, yeah, it's a bit weird innit how (inaudible)-
-but you know the truth you idiot!
How would I know which one I was?
So, anyway...
But bear in mind-
(exasperated) What would you do?
-you could pass him off as yourself.
What would you do? Would you play tricks wi-... would you uh...you know-
You could be in two places at once.
Would you do stings, would you do SCAMS-
-like Jackass!
No, because it would only end up getting me into trouble, won't it? Because people won't believe that there's another one like me.
Ricky makes an incoherent noise
Otherwise everyone would be saying that when they get caught robbin', they'd go, it wasn't me, it was me doppelganger.
Steve laughs, Ricky makes an incoherent noise

It can only-I wouldn't want it, to be honest. It's a-a-again, it's a bit of a headache, innit? Because he could be going off, going mental, causing all sorts of trouble and you'd go, "will you pack it in"?
Ricky snickers
And he's being, "what, what you on about?" But then that wouldn't happen, would it, because he's being me. So he'd be sat wherever I am anyway-
Ricky makes an incoherent noise
-because he'd want to do what I want to do. So pointless. But I still wouldn't want it.
Ricky laughs
It's unbelievable!
That was a conversation with himself.
That was amazing, we-
That was like, that was like experiencing what it would have been like if there was two Karls!
Yeah.
He was having a discussion with himself.

We could have left in that time and come back and he'd be arguing still. That is-that is officially the most stupid thing-if the Guinness World of Records is-has ANYONE, anywhere in the world said anything more stupid than "how would I know which one was me"?
But does this mean-
Steve laughs
-does this mean-
Ricky laughs
Steve chuckles
-does this mean though that I could just sit at home and not do anything....and just send me out on-
Yes.
An' he-an' he-when he-when he's seen something happen, I'm seeing it.
No, no no no, no.
You're separate people.
You're separate people.
But then he's not a doppelganger then is he-
(exasperated) Well, you're identical twins then, you found out-identical twins, and he's got the, exactly the same input as you. I mean, it's not a REAL question is it, it's just a little...AGAIN!
But I said to you the other week about twins and that how (incoherent) I wouldn't like to have a twin.
It's alright when you're a kid, but unless you're a Siamese twin, even they don't even look alike do they, they're just stuck together. You don't go, oh, don't they look like each other?
Ricky chuckles
They have different haircuts, they don't-they don't carry that thing on, do they, that normal twins do?
Ricky laughs
Like normal twins, the mams say, have the same haircut, wear the same shirt, Siamese twins....never look the same. They just...got their arse stuck together.
Again, it's a dialogue in his own head! It's unbelievable.
Transition music
Okay, we're trying to get more cerebral now in this-in this podcast, there's a lot of science here, REAL science, uhm-maybe we should call it a SPODcast.
Uhmhmm

Okay Karl...this is a-a-a-a-a logical...uhm-uh-conundrum-um...to a certain extent, there's a little bit of lateral thinking because uh-but there is only one right answer. Now, the pressure here isn't to get this right because I don't know anyone who's ever got this right. The pressure is one, a-a-asking sensible questions. And when I've TOLD you the answer, to then understand it. Because I've still, when I've EXPLAINED this to people, I've laid out for the-they still can't quite get the concept.
Um, okay, so...there's two doors, Karl.
Yeah.
One leads to heaven, one leads to hell. Okay. They're identical. You can't tell them apart. Okay, 50, 50.
Alright

Obviously you want to go to heaven, I assume? Right, there's two guards, identical guards guarding each door. Okay? The one guarding hell always tells a lie. The one guarding heaven always tells the truth. You have to ask one question to find out which...hich is which and then go through the door you want. What question do you ask?
I've only got one.
Yeah
And what? One to both?
No, one to either of them. You don't know which one's which, though. So what question do you ask?
Why can't I ask, like, both of them? One?
Because it's...the rules
Because the rules are you can only ask one. There aren't actually two doors labelled heaven and hell, Karl. That's a leap of imagination here.
And I've definitely got to ans... I've got to ask them a question. I can't just sort of have a feel of the door to see if there's any heat or anything.
Ricky laughs

They're identical. You stand a few yards away. You cannot tell from the outside of these doors which Is which, they're identical. The guards are identical. But the one guarding Hell always tells a lie. And the one guarding Heaven always tells the truth. What question do you ask?
I an't look through the keyhole or anything?
There's no keyhole near them.
Let's imagine there's a small rope that prevents you from getting anywhere near. Rather like outside a nightclub.
Yeah. What do you ask? What do you ask? What question do you ask? Come on, you only got one. Quick. This is it.
So they're stood there...
Yeah.
...they both look the same. They're both smiling.
Yeah.
But one of them's not really smiling really. He's trying to make me make a mistake, in' he?
Well, he's just gonna lie when you ask him a question if you ask him.
So what's the point in asking a question? Do I know one of them's gonna lie?
Yeah, well, you wont...The one guarding Hell always tells a lie. The one guarding Heaven always tells the truth. These...these things you know.
But would they be neighbours like this? Would they be that close?
Ricky laughs
Why...?
Steve laughs
I mean, we're not sure. If these two guys get along.
I'll give you a clue. I'll give you a clue. They know who they are and they know that the one guarding Hell always tells a lie and the one guard in Heaven always tells the truth.
So I know that.
No, they know it as well. It doesn't really come down to this, Karl. This isn't what's gonna happen when you die.
But when is this useful then?
Because it's a logic...well, I'll tell you the answer.
No no no, I want to see if he can get it. He's almost there.
Err...
No, he's not almost there. What am I thinking?

But there's no shame in not getting it. There's no shame in not getting it. It's a really hard one to get. What..what I mean, the shame is the ridiculous questions you asked. And now I'm gonna tell you he answer.
Hang on. Right, so you go up and you go, uhhhm...
Pause while Ricky quietly giggles
Hang on, let's-let's imagine that, let's imagine Ricky and I are those two guys. Okay? Right.
But we have to-um, uh, uh- well me and-me and Steve will decide which doors we're guarding. Okay?
(quietly) Right.
I'm...(chair moving sound)
L-look away, Karl.
Pause
Okay then.
Right, so we've decided, okay? One of us is guarding hell and one of us is guarding Heaven. Which question you're going to ask and who you gonna ask it to?
Pause
Right? Erm...I'll just say...to you Steve, I'll go uhh...uh...got some uh...got some post for God here.
Steve bursts into laughter
That's not a question. That's a statement.
Right you've got some post for God here.
But that's not a question.
((inaudible mumble. Alright?))
Yeah maybe the question's coming. You got some posts for God here, yeah.
Uh....(pause) and it needs to be signed.
It's not a question. Still not a question.
No, let him finish.
Is-is God in 'cos I need him to sign for this post. Is he in?
Well, I can answer that as well if you want.
Go on.
He-yeah, he's in. He's behind my door. Do you want to answer it?
Well--
Yes.
Do you want, do you want to get him, just uh...
Well, you only got one question.
So you're, you're asking Steve, "is God in?" What's the answer?
Yes.
Ask me. Yes.
Look, lads, I'm just trying to do a job here.
Steve laughs, Ricky snickers
Uhhm...what am I going to do with this?
Well, give it to me and I'll give it to God cuz he's behind my door. Steve?
Yeah, k-give it to me and I'll take it in to God 'cause he's behind my door.
You're an idiot. It doesn't help! That doesn't help. Let me tell you the answer.
Karl sighs
You ask either one of us....you say, "if I was to ask the other one, what door he was guarding, what would he say?"
Pause

Then whatever they say, is the door they're guarding. 'Cos if you happen to ask the one guarding hell, right, I'm guarding hell, by the way. I'm the devil, Steve's God, okay? So, you asked me, what, what Steve would say, if you asked him what door he was guarding. And I'm going to LIE. I know he'd say heaven because he'd tell the truth, but I'm lying, so I'd say, "he'd say hell". So you know I'm guarding hell. If you ask Steve what door I was guarding, he'd tell the truth, right? So he'd say....he'd say heaven because he'd know I'd lie. So he's guarding heaven. So the-the question is, "if I was to ask the other one what door he was guarding, what would he say?" And whatever the person answers is the door they're guarding.
Steve, what door are you....are you looking after?
Well...
Heaven.
Yeah.
Why should I believe ya?
Because, you don't know-no, that doesn't work, because you asked me the same and I'd say, heaven as well.
Right. So who do I believe? This is where you use your gut feeling though, innit?
Ricky bursts into laughter
This is what life's--
What, as opposed to the pure logic that Ricky's just used?
I just think- 'cause there's a lot of questions in life where you don't know the answer and you go, "do you know what? I don't like the look of him".
Steve chuckles
So--
They're identical.
Yeah, but they're still...identical twins, you always get a little snidey one.
Ricky bursts into laughter
Podcast theme plays
(in jingle voice) Oh, chimpanzee that, HE's WRITTEN IT DOWN! What a...c-(trails off into usual spasming)
Uh that's the jingle there for Karl's Diary. Still a very popular feature--
Ricky quietly giggles

--on show one/thirteen. Uh, here we are. (reading Karl's Diary) "Got a book sent to me called Freaks. It's a bit heavy but it's got some interesting pictures in it. Read a bit about...The Two Headed Nightingale. She/they was on tour in London years and years ago. It cost 2 shillings to have a front row seat. She/They had two heads/two arms and four legs. They are called Siamese twins because the first twins that were born stuck together were Siamese. On one of the pictures they are playing chess against a doctor. That hardly seems fair".
Ricky giggles
Two heads are better than one.
Steve chuckles
So it's two heads, two arms and four legs. That's just two women in one dress.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, that's two women with an arm missing.
(laughing) Yeah.

(reading Karl's Diary) "Spoke to Ricky and his friend Glynn about art. I just don't get it. Ricky had some odd pictures on his walls. I don't have any pictures up in my flat because of the mirrored wall, but I can't say I'm bothered." The mirrored wall, we should just explain what that is. When you moved into your flat, there was an enormous mirror on one wall, was that right?
We just got this flat--
Ricky quietly giggles

--and uhhh...you know, it's not a big flat, so I think the people who had it before us, he was a gay fella, right, which was a bit like "ohh so you've been doing with that mirror an' that". But that--
Ricky bursts into laughter
(flabbergasted noise) Whaaaat, what!?
No just, you know, jus--
What, what?
What has he been doing with the mirror?
What's he been d-why why why wh--
No, it's just 'cause they're quite sort of experimental an' that, aren't they and--
I don't know, what do you mean, what do they do?
Well, I wouldn't know anything about it, but gone.
((now would you, what?))
No I-I don't--
Experimental in what way?
What do you mean, what do you mean experimental?
I just mean, you know, they'd be doing stuff.
What?
Kind of whatever they do.
What?
Chemistry, they have a chemistry set out, they'd be doing experiments, what?
Singing "I am what I am" and just checking out their, the dance moves?
((no?)) I'm not having to go at anyone--
What?
--but I'm just saying, like they're doing what they're doing...uh...which ((it is annoying as well?))--
Karl you're not ((annoyed)) as well are ya?
No, I'm not, I'm not. This is what, why--
But why are you worried about what a little gay fella was doing in your flat before you got it in the front of a mirror?
I wasn't WORRIED about it.
Why are you THINKING about what he's doing? Why are you fantasizing what a little gay fella was doing in front of your mirror in your.
I'm-I'm-I'm not bothered! I'm just telling you what-why it was a bit odd that he had a mirror in there, right? But forget the-the history.
(amused) But you've got a mirror in there now, haven't ya?
No, because what I did was, I tried-I was gonna take it down....an' I thought, oh, it's a bit dangerous, this"--
(quietly) Yeah.
--you know, it could crack, and--
--'cause it's the size of the whole wall isn't it?
It too-t-took up a whole wall.
Right.
Alrite so like when he's moving about everywhere, he's got a good view of it an' that. But--
Ricky quietly giggles
--he's got this full wall of mirror. And I thought, I can't take that down.
Ricky's giggling intensifies
And uh...I thought, what-what can I do? So I've just, put wallpaper on it.
Brilliant.
And...it looks alright, y-you wouldn't know what have you. But it means that I can't put any pictures up. That's, that's all, that's all I'm saying. 'cause if I put a nail in it--
And what don't you understand about art? What about art, don't you understand? The concept? Specifics?
Just uhm...the way some people, like, you know, the ones you've got, where it's just like a block of color on a bit of canvas. It's like, what's, what's that?

Abstract. It's just abstract. It's-it's-you know, it's vibrancy of color. It's a, you know, an attack on the senses. Or it could be, there could be something in there that you might see, you might not see first time around. Or it could be, you know.
Yeah, but there's loads of stuff to look at without having to do that.
((inaudible, crosstalk))
You've got windows, I can understand if you had a cell and there's no windows and you want a bit of color--
Yeah.
--but you got a window to look out of and you've got like, just a big block of--
But--
--color on 'em.

--I was explaining this to you that th-th-th-the photograph of people-before, um, you know, th-art was photography, it was realistic, realistic and uh, you know, they had to make it look like the subject. But then, when cameras came in, that's when people started doing--
--Yeah, I--
--surreal stuff and ((because if?))--
I understand that.
--otherwise there was no point to it, they had to find a new way to represent things that uh-photography couldn't do as such.
No I-I-that's-that's like when we, when we were in London having a shop around at Christmas and there was that picture of fruit for 700 quid.
Ricky ((or steve?)) chuckles
Like, we'll just get ((incoherent stutter)) fruit, you know what I mean, you can get some real fruit for three quid.
Steve quietly chuckles
Yeah.
I understand that, but, there's nothing wrong with like, having a.....well get-don't-don't invent cameras then, one or the other. Do you know what I mean?
Ricky giggles

That's what annoys me. Someone invents something and then they go, we've got to invent something else. Like the abstract thing, why has someone gone "(clicks tongue) Oh I can't have paintings anymore because"--
What do you think of Dali? Going--
((describe this noise, karl saying i don't?))
--melting clocks and stuff ((incoherent))?
I mean the first one was alright when he did the first clock, but then, all the time he's just like, "oh I'll draw something, it's got a melting clock on it."
((yeah?))
I'll do a sheep, put, put one of them on it. Put a little clock on it.
Have you seen his lobster telephone?
That annoys me.
Why?
Because he's, he's just...it's not....it's not, I mean, what, I think what annoyed me more with that is, when I heard about how it happened. Um, he had some artist mate 'round--
Yeah.
Right? And, um...I don't know what happened uh they were eat--
Oh okay.
--they were eating--
That's a g-hell of an anecdote.
No no but they were eating. They were eating some food--
Yeah.
--and what have you.
Yeah.
Lobsters?
And uhh...yeah, th-they were eating lobster--
(sarcastically) Alright.
--and uhhhh--
That's handy.
--I don't know, the other artist, whoever it was--
((telephone?))
--started saying, "oh you and your clocks and all that", right--
Brilliant.
--and umm--
This didn't happen.
--they started, they started arguing--
Yeah.
--and, he chucked some of the lobster.
Bollocks!
(amused) And it landed on the phone?

It bounced off his mate's head. Went on the phone and they both looked at each other like, "are you thinking what I'm thinking"? And th-they brought out that phone as a bit of art. Things like that annoy me...--
Didn't happen.
--because it was them just messing about.
That didn't happen.
Just telling you what I know. I saw his, his work. Each to their own, if that's what he's doing. I'm just saying, I'm not...putting my stamp of approval on it.
Ricky laughs, Steve chuckles
Heaven forbid! Well, um, you know, as you mentioned in your diary, your FAVOURITE artist is Lowry, "'cause you can look at them for ages and see someone different every time you look at it".
All I'm saying is.....art should be there to tell a story, not just to have a splash of colour. We know colour's out there, there's loads of colour.
Steve quietly chuckles
We don't need to be reminded of it.
Steve laughs
But colour's part of our evolution and so...it does something to us.
Pause
Only--
--just like sounds, just like sounds.
Yeah but I'm saying, do a picture--
--smells--
--color it in! Still use the colors--
Mm.
--but draw something with it rather than just going...bit of yellow, a bit of red, like that when you've got just red and black. What, what, what's that meant to do?
Well, it does something.
What?
Well, I like it, I enjoy it. So it does something.
((inaudible)) yeah, you have it then. I'm just saying I'd prefer it if it WAS something.
And so you wh-let me just get straight, you had a mirror on one wall, so you, you padded that wall.
It's just sort of, it's just--
--and you've padded the others?
It's just sort of uh, wallpaper on it.
Right.
Amazing.
And there's no other art in there--
((incoherent))
--just a empty cell?
Was Suzanne ((incoherent)) like some art? Just like to (incoherent stutter) "Suzanne's not allowed to watch telly unless it's her favorite thing, otherwise she's got to talk to me--
Steve chuckles
--about stuff. There's no art, there's no point, just waaaallpaaaper".
I'm just saying, we've got three, three windows we can look out of.
Right.
Right?
Ricky quietly chuckles
Stop looking at the walls, look out the window.
Ricky laughs
(reading Karl's Diary) "Some new words have been introduced into the dictionary. Too many words!"
Ricky giggles
(reading Karl's Diary) "We should have some system where we can get rid of words if they aren't used a certain number of times".
Well ((incoherent stutter)), we do.
They do die out, don't they, eventually.
Like what?
You don't have to use 'em.
No, but they don't do they, they keep adding them. And I just worry about...uh...you know, this is the problem with, like, your head can only hold so much...
Ricky sniffs
Can't it?
Yeah.
It, all very well when, Adam and Eve was knocking about. There's no history, they don't have to remember anything.
Ricky giggles
